confession.seduction_context: on way to Fossarux; asked if she would believe in him, promising to make her happy. Gave her money to buy bread, but it turned out to be wood
powder_types: black powder to kill people and animals
sabbat_activities: danced to sound of drum and musette
led by several devils in black

testimony.quarrel_subject: Payment dispute - he had paid her husband for carting stones, but she came and demanded payment again

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: after quarrel around St Martin, until Whitsun

testimony.quarrel_subject: Exchange of a horse with her husband, asked for a stick to beat it with
Daughter of witness kept driving away accused's sow from outside their house and called her witch
testimony.threat_quote: threatened to make her shut up

witnesses.name: Collatte fille Colas Chaisne de Ste Margarée

testimony.quarrel_subject: Remarked that they had killed an animal but given accused nothing, forebade witness to say anything to other servant. Witness broke the broom.
Lost shirt when invited into house during washing
Refused to sell accused a pig at the price she offered
testimony.threat_quote: she would not have much profit from it

testimony.quarrel_subject: Urged husband not to give up lease of a cow which accused wanted to take over; also dispute over dried pears during Lent

witnesses.name: Bastien Marande
witnesses.occupation: fournier au four banal du chapitre

testimony.quarrel_subject: Accused said he had not called her in time with her bread
testimony.threat_quote: went off down street cursing and threatening

witnesses.name: Colas le Viel de Saincte Helaine
witnesses.occupation: jeune fils mulnier à St Dié

timeline.subject: Barbeline Wanesson
timeline.details: First interrogation; denied all charges, showed black cross on forearm made with holy water

timeline.subject: Barbeline Wanesson
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves question ordinaire et extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Barbeline Wanesson
timeline.details: Tortured with thumbscrews, rack, and tortillons; eventually confessed under torture

timeline.subject: Barbeline Wanesson
timeline.details: Repeated confessions, racked again to extract more accomplice names

timeline.subject: Barbeline Wanesson
timeline.details: Change de Nancy orders new interrogation without executioner present, concerned torture was repeated too often

timeline.subject: Barbeline Wanesson
timeline.details: Retracted all previous confessions, said they were forced from her

timeline.subject: Barbeline Wanesson
timeline.details: Change de Nancy recommends torture again 'avec mediocrité' (with moderation)

timeline.subject: Barbeline Wanesson
timeline.details: Threat of further torture enough to make her renew confessions

timeline.subject: Barbeline Wanesson
timeline.details: Death sentence confirmed by Change de Nancy

timeline.subject: Barbeline Wanesson
timeline.details: Found dead in prison; apothecary concluded she died from cold and privations of long imprisonment

torture.restrictions: Second round ordered 'avec mediocrité' (with moderation) due to concerns about excessive torture

accomplices_named.name: Mengeatte femme Jean Thierry dit l'Allemand (l'hospitaliere)
accomplices_named.context: Named as accomplice at sabbat; this woman had originally accused Barbeline

accomplices_named.name: wife of Jean Diez
accomplices_named.context: Named as accomplice at sabbat; confronted in prison, denied charges

accomplices_named.name: Mengeatte from Viel Marché
accomplices_named.context: Named as accomplice under additional torture

accomplices_named.name: Dion wife of Colas Babon
accomplices_named.context: Named as accomplice; also called 'le peu Bourrat'

accomplices_named.name: la femme Holbin des Trois Maisons
accomplices_named.context: Named then discharged, saying she only knew of her by hearsay

accomplices_named.name: wife of le Grand Masson du Molinet

prior_accusations.accuser_name: Mengeatte femme Jean Thierry dit l'Allemand (l'hospitaliere)
prior_accusations.context: Accused Barbeline of seeing her and her late husband at the sabbat

notable_quotes.speaker: Barbeline Wanesson
notable_quotes.french: gentil fils dieu, Roy de tout le monde, qu'est ce qu'on peult dire, et qu'est ce qu'on luy peult imputer, que c'est ung terrible monde. S'escriant, ach Jean le Rouyer, pense à ta conscience, qu'elle ne veult pas dire ce qui n'est pas, et ce qu'elle ne fit oncques
notable_quotes.english: gentle son of God, King of all the world, what can one say, and what can one impute to her, what a terrible world this is. Crying out, ah Jean le Rouyer, think of your conscience, that she does not want to say what is not true, and what she never did
notable_quotes.context: Response during initial interrogation when asked about illness of Jean le Rouyer

notable_quotes.speaker: Barbeline Wanesson
notable_quotes.french: Ach Jesus bon dieu, ses bonnes voisines ont elles telle opinion contre elle, que par pitie de la famine, qu'elle ly veoit endurer, elle l'a secouru plusieurs fois de ses biens, et que c'est le remerciement qu'on luy faict
notable_quotes.english: Ah Jesus good God, do her good neighbors have such opinion against her, that out of pity for the famine she saw him endure, she helped him several times with her goods, and this is the thanks she receives
notable_quotes.context: Response when asked about wife of Hidoult Cognolle losing milk

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean le Rouyer (via Barbeline)
notable_quotes.context: What Barbeline allegedly said when Jean le Rouyer asked for stick to beat horse

notable_quotes.speaker: Barbeline Wanesson
notable_quotes.french: l'appetit de l'argent qu'il luy debvoit
notable_quotes.english: the appetite for money that he owed her
notable_quotes.context: Comment during torture about Joseph Bouray bringing her to this state

relationships.evidence_text: daughter of Claude de la Lealbe of St Lyenard
her husband had carted some stones for him
had exchanged a horse with her husband
had been in service with grand doyen Fournier
invited into house in customary way when they were washing, as neighbour
Accused was close neighbour to barn

economic_context.details: Multiple disputes over payments and economic transactions: Joseph Bouray over payment for carting stones; dispute over cow lease; refused to sell pig at offered price; quarrel over bread timing at oven; complaint about not receiving meat from slaughtered animal. The trial reveals economic tensions and Barbeline's acts of charity (helping neighbors with food during famine) which she referenced in her defense.

harms_catalog.harm_description: Became ill until Whitsun, eating normally but losing use of limbs and becoming 'quasy asmaticqz' (quasi asthmatic)
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Payment dispute over carting stones; he called her witch and she threatened him
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: after quarrel around last St Martin
harms_catalog.method_alleged: Counter-magic healing through bread, salt and ashes from her house

harms_catalog.harm_description: Struck his own foot instead of horse, tremendous pain, so ill he was expected to die. His spirits revived after drinking soup with magical ingredients
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Asked for stick to beat horse after exchange, she said 'may the drunkards be cursed'
harms_catalog.method_alleged: Counter-magic healing through items obtained from her house made into soup

harms_catalog.harm_description: Started to bleed from nose and mouth for two weeks, then vomited up strange stone - pebble at one end, salt at the other
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Daughter kept driving away accused's sow and called her witch, accused threatened to make her shut up
harms_catalog.method_alleged: witchcraft manifesting as stone inside body

harms_catalog.harm_description: Became frightened in hayloft and fell out, hurting herself badly. Unable to walk although nothing visibly wrong
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Broke accused's broom; accused remarked they killed animal but gave her nothing and forbade her to tell other servant
harms_catalog.method_alleged: Counter-magic healing through bread, salt, and ashes from accused's house

harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Angry because she had not been asked to help with harvesting; had been in stable previous night

harms_catalog.harm_description: Lost voice for 10 weeks, then recovered
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Lost shirt when invited into house during washing
harms_catalog.method_alleged: Something she gave child to eat caused illness and cure
Milk returned after accused made her a soup

harms_catalog.victim_name: Claudatte veuve Georgeon Rasaille and son
harms_catalog.harm_description: Became very ill; could not bear sight of pork
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Refused to sell accused a pig at the price she offered
Told 'she would not have much profit from it'

harms_catalog.harm_description: Became seriously ill; recovered and gave birth a week after meeting accused at Easter
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Urged husband not to give up lease of a cow which accused wanted; also dispute over dried pears during Lent
Quarrelled because she said he had not called her in time with her bread; went off cursing and threatening
Quarrel over bread timing at oven
none - confessed to killing own animal
none - confessed to killing own animal

harms_catalog.method_alleged: black powder; could be cured with bread, salt, ashes, and 'joutte' from garden

harms_catalog.harm_description: Death of horse which seemed to be rabid

prior_legal_disputes.description: Joseph Bouray - accused alleged she had obtained reparation from him; judges suggested this was false; her husband had taken legal action

legal_context.redress_outcome: Could not seek reparation from Jehennon veuve Colas Henriot for calling her witch because she had no witnesses
legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: Died from cold and other privations caused by long imprisonment (59 days total, about 2 months)

hearsay_chains.content: Helped to get counter-magic substances from accused's house for Jean le Rouyer

emotional_state_notes: Cried out loudly when given thumbscrews
Made emotional appeals to Jesus and God
Expressed frustration at being falsely accused
Started to waver when brought back to torture chamber
Asked if judges would take sin on themselves if she said something she should not

extraction_metadata.notes: This is a particularly detailed and tragic case. The trial record shows extensive torture that was noted as excessive even by contemporary standards - the Change de Nancy specifically ordered a new interrogation without the executioner present because they believed torture had been repeated too often. The accused retracted her confession, calling it forced, then renewed it under threat of more torture. She died in prison from cold and privations before execution could be carried out. The case reveals significant economic tensions, debt disputes, and a pattern of counter-magic healing rituals using bread, salt, and ashes from the accused's house. Notable that accused showed judges a protective black cross on her forearm made with holy objects, and referenced her charitable acts of helping neighbors during famine - suggesting complex religious practices and community relations.
